Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Economics: Convex Preferences Over Lotteries

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds research that the coPI will undertake as part of his doctoral dissertation. He will conduct decision making experiments in a laboratory environment. The goal is to test whether the participants behave in the specific ways predicted by economic theory. The coPI will use a new experimental design to test hypotheses drawn from different models of choice under risk that are used in behavioral economics. This new design has more power and does not require specific assumptions that are needed by other experimental designs. The experiments can be adapted to investigate a wide variety of issues, from decision making over time to the effect of altruism on economic decisions. The project will help us better understand how people make important economic decisions. The results could improve our understanding of how to encourage Americans to plan for retirement and contribute to their communities.

The project seeks to test competing theories of decision making under risk, theories that are alternatives to the standard expected utility theory. The coPI plans to use an elicitation and testing procedure to acquire choices from a convex lottery space. The design will allow him to discriminate between competing theories. The design elicits the convex lower contour set of indifference curves in the probability simplex. This works because many properties of preferences over lotteries can be studied in the probability simplex with "budget lines" in this space. The experiments will test to see whether or not agents strictly prefer more prizes to fewer prizes, and therefore they will provide new evidence on whether or not strict quasiconcavity is a reasonable assumption on individual preferences over lotteries.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF outcomes report:
Understanding whether individuals have preferences for mixtures of lotteries, different chances of different monetary outcomes, is critical for our understanding of decisionmaking under uncertainty. We say an individual has a preference for mixtures if they choose to receive at least two distinct lotteries with some positive chance. The traditional model rules out a preference for mixtures as preferences over outcomes are assumed to be `independent' from the likelihoods with which they occur. Preferences for mixtures can help us understand why individual choice behavior need not be stationary---chosen alternatives are not always the same across repeated decisions. Further, it can explain the benefit of adding additional monetary prizes to a lottery which the traditional model cannot. By studying preference for mixtures we can provide evidence that individuals might not have deterministic preferences over uncertain outcomes, in the sense of always picking the same lottery from the same set of alternatives.

Intellectual Merit:
In this project we sought to investigate whether individuals have a preference for mixtures, whether these preferences for mixtures can be explained by a well-behaved preference relation---can be represented by a simple mathematical model---, and if these preferences are related to chosen alternatives not always being constant across repetitions. For example, consider somebody that always flips two coins to decide whether to eat a burger or a salad. Let's say this person only chooses salad if two heads come up, that is with a one-in-four chance. If we asked this same person whether he wanted either a burger or a salad, four times in a row, it would be sensible to expect this person to say salad once and burger three times. This is how we relate preferences for mixtures to non-stationary choice behavior across repetitions. This extends the mounting evidence that individuals might be deliberately random in their choices when choosing between lotteries, or more generally, in choices involving uncertainty.

To elicit these preferences for mixtures, we elicited preferences over three-outcome lotteries in a manner that mimics the stripped-down version of a consumer's problem. In modern microeconomics, the quintessential consumer problem is choosing over two goods given a finite amount of dollars and prices for these two goods. For our setup, rather than trading off two goods, our subjects tradeoff the chance of a middle outcome, $10, against the chances of both the lowest and the highest outcome, respectively $2 and $30. By increasing the latter chances they increase the potential reward and the risk. Given that this version of risky decisionmaking mimics the standard consumer budgetary problem we can utilize the machinery of consumer theory to determine whether choices are consistent with a downward sloping demand schedule, whether there exists a function that can summarize behavior, and we can directly relate it to repeated choices across the alternatives. Our findings confirm that choices are consistent with a downward sloping demand schedule, can be represented by a well-behaved utility function, and are informative about the frequency with which alternatives are chosen across repetitions.

Broader Impact:
A plethora of everyday choices feature some uncertainty as to their likely outcomes. For this reason, understanding how these choices are made is critical to our understanding of decisionmaking. Extending our understanding of decisionmaking under uncertainty can help us understand how to both develop better models and help organize prior empirical findings. Moreover, it has immediate policy relevance as preferences for mixtures can be used to tailor stronger incentives in most contexts. For example, prosocial behavior can be bolstered by using multiple risky outcomes at no greater (expected) cost. This provides a channel through which individuals can be incentivized to pursue more altruistic actions without higher out-of-pocket costs.

This project highlights how we can extend the machinery of modern microeconomic theory straightforwardly. On top of that, our research suggests that the likely explanation that choice behavior appears random because it is random is empirically refuted. Not only do we reject this hypothesis in our context; we also provide a way to elicit these preferences for mixtures using our methodology. Future studies now have an increasing number of tools that they can employ to make choice behavior that appears random more tractable. We encourage future research to study whether our results extend to broader environments.
